Graphical abstract The catalytic performance for Water Gas Shift Reaction and surface species at reaction conditions were studied by operando-DRIFTS of the bare Pr-promoted Ce oxide support, two supported monometallic Cu and Ni, and a bimetallic CuNi catalyst. All samples were thoroughly characterised by Operando-DRIFTS across a range of temperatures (150–375 °C) and two distinct reaction atmospheres: CO–H2O and CO–H2O–H2. The results demonstrated that the nature of the surrounding atmosphere significantly influences the surface chemistry and product distribution. The reactivity was as follows: CePr < Cu/CePr < CuNi/CePr < Ni/CePr. However, the selectivity towards CO2 was CePr=Cu/CePr > CuNi/CePr > Ni/CePr due to the tendency to produce CH4 (on Ni-containing catalysts) when H2 was present in the reaction feed. Hence, under oxidising conditions (absence of hydrogen), formate species were stabilised on CePr and Ni/CePr surfaces, indicating a predominant associative mechanism. In contrast, Cu-containing catalysts (Cu/CePr and CuNi/CePr) favoured carbonate formation and suppressed formate accumulation, promoting a redox-type pathway. Under reducing conditions (presence of H2), Ni facilitated CH4 formation via methanation, particularly on Ni/CePr. The bimetallic CuNi/CePr catalyst behaved similarly to Cu/CePr under CO–H2O feed, showing no stable formates, but in the presence of H2, methane formation and surface-stabilised formates were observed—mimicking the behaviour of Ni/CePr. These findings highlight the role of Cu in modulating the electronic and adsorptive properties of Ni, weakening formate adsorption and delaying methanation, thus enhancing CO2 selectivity. Overall, the CuNi/CePr system emerges as a complex multimetallic catalyst that adapts to both oxidising and reducing environments, improving WGS performance through a balanced interplay between redox and hydrogenation pathways. Keywords WGS CuNi Pr-promoted ceria Operando-DRIFTS Mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Water Gas Shift (WGS), CO + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + H 2 , is a relevant reaction for the industry with increasing interest in the last three decades due to its role as a suitable first step in the CO removal pathway from H2-rich streams for PEM fuel cells. Although catalysts are commercially available (mostly based on FeCr and CuZnAl mixed oxides) these catalytic systems industrially employed are still not adequate for conducting this reaction in the fuel cell context due to their low activity, excessive required contact time, and pyrophoricity [1]. To overcome these difficulties different formulations of catalysts were studied, involving a wide diversity of transition metals as active phases like Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Au, Ag, Cu, Ni, and Co, a relevant span of supports such as alumina, silica, ceria, activated carbon, basic oxides, and other rare-earth oxides. Additionally, alkali metals or rare-earth metals were used as promoters, K, Na, Mg, La, and Pr [2–7]. Thus, the possible combination led to a myriad of catalysts. Solids based on noble metals often showed a moderate-to-high CO conversion, but with high associated costs. On the other hand, catalytic systems using transition metals are a cost-effective alternative, Cu catalysts showed a relevant but moderate activity, whilst Ni often presented a higher performance. However, Ni-based catalysts also exhibited some selectivity towards undesired reactions, such as CO and CO2 methanation, depending on whether H2 is included in the feed stream of the reactor [8]. During the past few years, a group of bimetallic catalysts have been studied, showing promising outcomes. The combination of active metals represents a suitable approach to overcome the weak points of the Fe or Cu commercial monometallic catalysts by a possible synergy of both present metals. The Co-Ru synergistic couple was studied for WGS and CO methanation [9]. PtNi bimetallic alloys were successfully tested at reaction conditions with methanation inhibition [10]. Pd-Cu and Pt-Cu supported over ceria were tested for oxygen-enhanced WG,S presenting a higher CO conversion and H2 production than their monometallic counterparts due to the alloy identified by EXAFS [11]. Au-Pt solids over ceria exhibited the highest activity in comparison with other catalytic systems Au-Me (Me=Ni, Cu, Ag, Pd), being the Pt responsible for the formation of partly oxidised gold species, probably due to the interatomic charge transfer from Au 5d to Pt 5d band [12]. Among different possible bimetallic combinations, Cu-Ni is an interesting couple of cost-efficient elements in comparison with permutations including noble metals. A series of Cu-Ni solids supported over ceria, promoted ceria, and activated carbon have been studied during the last 15 years as promising catalysts for the WGS reaction. All authors claimed that the copper incorporation into the nickel-based catalyst enhanced the activity and greatly improved the selectivity towards WGS, hindering the undesired methanation of the carbon oxides. A Cu-Ni alloy was identified in some of these samples, and it was suggested as responsible for the improved performance [13]. The strong interaction between the active metals has a double positive effect, to increase the higher energy barrier for the dissociation of the adsorbed CO and to decrease the CO adsorption heat, resulting in a higher activity and selectivity [14]. Since the Cu-Ni interaction most likely determines the selectivity, it is expected that the reaction mechanism may also be influenced. It is worth mentioning that in most cases, the works with CuNi bimetallic solids are focused on determining the enhanced activity of the bimetallic couple. The proper determination of the WGS reaction mechanism operating in the monometallic or bimetallic catalysts based on Cu or Ni over ceria has been explored by combining different techniques with relative success, in situ DRIFTS, XRD, EXAFS/XANES, and SSITKA [15]. Density Functional Theory also proved to be very effective in elucidating a microkinetic and the possible intermediates [16]. A redox mechanism was proposed to operate, at least at a moderately high temperature, based on the results of the analysis obtained for CeO2-supported Cu samples [17]. However, associative mechanisms involving interfacial carboxylate or carbonate species have also been reported and could operate at lower temperatures in the same samples [18]. Regarding Ni-based catalysts, the study of reaction performance was often conducted in hydrogen absence highly favouring the WGS. In this case, some authors concluded that an associative and a redox mechanism may be present for Ni/CeO2 samples depending on the reaction temperature, benefiting the redox path at high temperatures, whilst the associative via bidentate formates is preferential at lower temperatures [19]. It was reported that, after ceria reduction, geminal OH groups are formed in the support surface and react with the previously generated formates, decomposing into products [20]. Other works were focused on studying the effect of a promoter in the inhibition of methanation, such as alkaline metals. In the case of Ni-K catalysts, the potassium incorporation induced an increase in the density of hydroxyl groups reactive with previously CO-adsorbed form surface formate as reaction intermediates [21]. On the other hand, the study of a Ni-K/CeO2 catalyst indicated that the K addition enhanced the dissociation of H2O on reduced ceria in H and OH to further form active oxygen capable of oxidising the adsorbed CO [22]. This redox path indicates that the reaction mechanism strongly depends on the bimetallic active phase and support interaction. In the present work, the bare support, Pr-promoted ceria, the monometallic Cu and Ni-based catalysts, and a bimetallic CuNi catalyst were studied by operando-DRIFTS with the aim of determining the influence of the active phase on the activity and selectivity towards WGS. Heat and mass transfer limitations were assessed, and the apparent activation energy was calculated and compared to previous values obtained in a fixed-bed reactor. The surface species were studied at different temperatures, and the influence of hydrogen content at the reaction feed was analysed. In addition, effort has been made to identify the reaction path, redox or associative and the possible reaction intermediates. Carbonates were ubiquitous whilst formates were absent in the copper catalyst and the bimetallic in hydrogen absence. The redox reaction path seemed to be the most relevant mechanism for these solids in agreement with the high redox activity found in previous works [23,24]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample synthesis The studied catalysts in the present work were obtained by incipient wetness impregnation of the Pr-promoted ceria support previously obtained by co-precipitation of both cations by urea decomposition at 90 °C. The solid precursor was washed, filtered, and calcined in air for 5 h at 450 °C. The Pr to Ce ratio was fixed in order to obtain a Pr content of 15 at.%; details were reported elsewhere [24]. The wet impregnation of the calcined support was conducted by employing the corresponding metal salts: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Sigma 98.0 %) and/or Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck 99.0 %). The concentrations were adjusted in order to obtain the desired metal loading of 10 %wt. for each catalyst using a salt volume of 0.85 cm3 per gram of solid. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried in a stove at 70 °C for 24 h and subsequently calcined in static air at 450 °C for 5 h with a 10 °C/min ramp from RT. The catalysts used in this work were prepared with nominal metal contents of ca. 10 wt%, including a bimetallic catalyst (Cu:Ni, 1:1 mass ratio). Finally, the obtained samples were named CePr, Cu/CePr, CuNi/CePr and Ni/CePr. 2.2 DRIFTS analysis The four samples were characterised by Operando-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) performed on a Nicolet 6700 infrared spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) equipped with an MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. All experiments were performed using a Dual sample chamber Smart collector DRIFTS cell (THERMO scientific) with ZnSe windows. For the steady-state analysis, the spectra were obtained by collecting 200 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Samples were placed in the cell without packing or dilution. The gases at the exit of the cell were analysed by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 320) following m/z = 2, 4, 14, 15, 16, 18, 28, 32, 40, and 44 amu. Once the catalyst (ca. 20 mg) was placed in the cell, it was reduced with H2/Ar (10 %, 60 NTP cm3/min) for 30 min at 350 °C (heating rate 5 °C/min). This procedure ensured the reduction of the surface since the used catalysts were briefly exposed to air during loading. After reduction, the cell was cooled to reaction temperature, and the feed was changed to CO-H2O/Ar 53 NTP cm3/min with a 1–3 mol ratio for CO-H2O and 1–3-20 for CO-H2O-H2; He was used as an internal standard. The steady-state experiments were carried out after the stabilisation at one temperature over time, then, a spectrum of the studied sample was collected and a quick step in the temperature was performed in order to repeat the procedure. The reaction temperature was changed by 50 °C steps between 150 and 350 °C. During this period, the gas phase was continuously monitored by mass spectrometry. Prior to all changes, the background was taken on the sample before introducing the gaseous reactants with the aim of determining the difference of the solid surface species between each reaction state. The transient response analysis was carried out by applying rapid changes in the reaction atmosphere using a four-way valve. The H2O/Ar feed was rapidly switched to the previously mentioned mixture of CO and H2O by a CO step. Alternatively, to determine the hydrogen effect on the reaction performance of the solids, the standard CO-H2O reaction atmosphere was quickly changed to CO-H2O-H2/Ar after a H2 step. A spectra series was collected under all carried out experiments, acquiring several spectra every 0.2 min after the induced change in the reaction atmosphere. The sample surface before the reaction step was used as a background for each spectrum with the purpose of observing the proper surface changes due to the introduction of a test molecule. All tests were conducted in isothermal conditions. 2.3 Preliminary analysis The samples were submitted to a steady-state analysis at different temperatures in order to study the behaviour of the surface species whilst measuring the gas phase composition to determine the catalytic activity of the samples, Fig. S1, Fig. S2. Then, these measurements were employed to calculate the activation energy. The heat and mass transfer limitations for the obtained results in the DRIFTS cell were assessed by the Anderson, Mears, and Weisz-Prater criteria. Most IR commercial cells that are proper for conducting IR characterisation often suffer from a series of issues when employed for catalytic studies, hindering their application as a chemical reactor. This is due to poor sealing, large dead volume, temperature and concentration gradients along the catalyst bed, and bypassed flows, leading to misguided conclusions and a complex data interpretation; an interesting summary can be found elsewhere [25]. Thus, it is not common to find a mass and heat transfer limitation assessment for DRIFTS studies due to the complexity of the fluid dynamics of the IR cells. In effect, most of the works dealing with IR studies at either In-situ or Operando conditions involve microreactors where heat and mass transfer are greatly improved and adequately determined [26], but these fluid dynamics conditions are not necessarily the same as they can be found in an IR commercial cell. Consequently, the heat and mass transfer limitations were calculated by considering different approaches as stated in the literature for microchannels and fixed bed reactors [27,28] and should be taken as merely indicative (detailed calculation in Table S1 in Supplementary material). Anderson criterion was applied to assess heat transport limitation, whilst Mears and Wiesz-Prater criteria were employed to rule out external and internal mass transfer limitations, respectively. Table S2 summarise this analysis and demonstrates that none of the measurements presented heat or interparticle mass transfer limitations. Regarding intraparticle mass transfer, the experiments on CePr support presented no significant limitation. On the other hand, the catalysts exhibited questionable values at the highest temperature analysed, but acceptable values below the criterion at lower temperatures in the case of the monometallic Cu catalyst, and close values to the criterion in the case of Ni-containing solids. The apparent activation energy was calculated by Arrhenius plots, avoiding the CO conversion values at the highest temperatures due to the observed deviation of the reaction rate, Fig. S3. As a result, the calculated Eap value for the bare support (75 kJ/mol) is close to the formerly obtained in a fixed bed reactor (81 kJ/mol [23]), signifying less than a 10 % difference. In the case of the monometallic Cu catalyst, the value of 46.6 kJ/mol found for this analysis was very close to the 42 kJ/mol obtained from the fixed bed reactor tests [14]. Therefore, it can be affirmed the obvious conclusion that WGS reaction is taking place in both conducted analyses. On the other hand, both Ni-containing catalysts presented a different trend. The bimetallic sample showed a lower activation energy for the IR experiments in comparison with the fixed bed reactor study, 51 kJ/mol and 82 kJ/mol, respectively [14]. This may suggest that the WGS reaction is not purely taking place, indicating some limitations in this case. Regarding the activation energy calculated for the Ni sample, it can be observed a relevant difference between both values, almost half, between DRIFTS, and fixed bed reactor, 38 and 70 kJ/mol, respectively [14]. The Ni-containing catalysts showed a relevant CO conversion in comparison with the bare support and the monometallic Cu solid. Based on the estimated reaction rate and transport parameters, the Weisz-Prater criterion showed a possible mass transfer limitation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Steady-state Operando-DRIFTS analysis All samples were submitted to WGS reaction conditions in the presence of CO and H2O simultaneously in an attempt to characterise the species present on the surface of the solids at different temperatures and identify the possible mechanism. Additionally, the catalysts were also tested in more real conditions in the presence of a high H2 content with the purpose of determining whether a possible effect of the superficial species was observed. All spectra were acquired in steady state and exhibited differences in the four regions of interest, 3200–3800 cm−1, 2700–3000 cm−1, 2000–2400 cm−1 and 1050–1800 cm−1, corresponding to O–H stretching mode of hydroxyls, formate vibrations, CO2(g) and C=O stretching mode of carbon monoxide bound to catalyst surface, and carbonates together with other oxo compounds. Since the complexity of the 1200–1800 cm−1 region for these samples, the fitting of the spectra was attempted to properly determine the species present. A summary of the results is reported in Table 1 whilst the fitted spectra can be found in Supplementary material. As can be observed, several species were identified with a major presence of carbonates as is expected in this support [29,30]. Some other species were recognised but dependent on the active metal or the reaction conditions such as formates (m- H C O O 2 - , b- H C O O 2 - ), bicarbonate (m- H C O 3 - ), bridged carbonate (br- C O 3 = ), CH4 (g), or carboxylate ( C O 2 δ + ). 3.1.1 Study of the temperature effect on superficial species of the bare CePr support The bare support showed quite a few adsorbed compounds characterised by a complex spectrum, see Fig. 1 a. In the high wavenumber region located between 3200–3800 cm−1, different –OH species were found in agreement with the prevailing reaction condition including steam in the rection feed. Some authors reported mono, bridged, and multiple coordinated hydroxyls to ceria support as well as a shift in the ν(OH) values according to the reduction state of Ce in the lattice [41]. The main observed band close to 3506 cm−1 agrees with the value reported for pre-reduced samples tested in the presence of CO or CO-H2O [42]. This was ascribed to multiple coordinated hydroxyls, whilst the sharp peak lying at 3640 cm−1 was reported as bridging-OH. Additionally, a shoulder was observed close to 3693 cm−1 and assigned to mono-coordinated hydroxyl. With a temperature increase, a decrease in the intensity of the whole region was observed indicating a possible cleaning of residual hydroxyls, and/or a conversion to intermediates/products. This is the case of the band of the multiple coordinated –OH or the mono-OH which was observed up to 250 °C and then disappeared. However, the bridged hydroxyl practically did not change, remaining strongly attached to the surface. The group of peaks observed in the range 2700–3000 cm−1, a triplet at first sight, agreed with the commonly reported bands for formates in diverse studied supports according to the literature [43,44]. These are very relevant species because are often assumed as reaction intermediates for Water Gas Shift reaction. The three clearly defined peaks found at wavenumbers 2933, 2838, and 2725 cm−1, were in coincidence with the signals reported for b- H C O O 2 - of ceria-supported catalysts, ν(CH), ν(CO2) + δ(CH), and 2δ(CH) respectively, [32,45]. After careful observation of the peak of the centre of the triplet (maximum at 2838 cm−1), a very small blue shoulder can be found close to 2849 cm−1. Hence, it can be assumed that the latter peak is ascribed to the ν(CH) of m- H C O O 2 - [46]. Some authors reported that the different bands of formates species may depend on the redox state of cerium ions instead of different coordinated species to the ceria support (mono or bidentate) [47]; it is possible that the same behaviour should be expected for Pr3+ and Pr4+ due to the similarity of both elements, Ce and Pr. However, this band assignation may be ruled out in the present analysis due to no further reduction of the mixed oxide should be expected during the conducted tests after the activation pre-treatment with H2 (conducted at the highest operating temperature). Regarding the temperature effect, the peak intensity of these species was modified along the conducted tests exhibiting the lower values at 150 and 300 °C and the maximum at 250 °C in agreement with the trend reported by Li et al. with a maximum intensity close to 200 °C [40]. This signifies that two opposing effects were involved in formates stability when the reaction temperature was modified, on the one hand, a temperature increment improved the reaction between CO and H2O to produce these compounds, but on the other, a higher temperature tended to benefit the reverse decomposition to CO. This is supported by the fact that the highest CO2 production was found at 350 °C and different authors demonstrated that the activation energy of the reverse decomposition in the presence of water was much higher than the forward reaction [36,48]. The analysis of the region lying between 2000–2400 cm−1 showed some signals in the spectra in agreement with the positions often reported for CO2 (g), 2360, 2340 cm−1, and CO (g), 2170 and 2125 cm−1 [49]. Nevertheless, there is some disagreement in the literature regarding the two latter bands because some authors claimed that these are related to adsorbed CO on partially reduced ceria. The peak at higher wavenumber was assigned to CO linearly adsorbed on Ce4+ (reported at 2165, 2170, or 2177 cm−1), and the one located at 2152–2156 cm−1 to CO on Ce4+ in a more unsaturated coordination state. Regarding Ce3+, it was reported that the CO adsorbed on this cation shows a peak at lower wavenumbers at very different locations such as 2120, 2127, 2140, or 2157 cm−1 [34,50]. In addition, an identifiable band of the forbidden 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 electronic transition (allowed in non-stoichiometric ceria) is normally reported at 2120–2130 cm−1 [51]; an exhaustive discussion can be found elsewhere [52]. As a result, the manifestation of this observed band indicating some extent of ceria reduction might be misperceived since CO adsorption can be also assigned to different but close positions [53]. According to this, the collected spectra of the CePr mixed oxide in the present work probably showed a combination of all mentioned features in the 2050–2230 cm−1 range (CO adsorbed on Ce4+, on Ce3+, and electronic transition), due to the reducibility of the sample. The evolution of these signals with the reaction temperature has shown a value practically constant up to 250 °C, with a notable increase at higher temperatures. This is in agreement with the intensity decrease of formates bands previously ascribed to backward decomposition producing adsorbed CO. The complex convoluted profile between 1200 and 1800 cm−1 was analysed; the fitted spectrum is reported in Fig. S4 and the positions of the corresponding peaks are in Table 1. The poly and bidentate carbonates dominated the spectrum with minor contributions of the monodentate type and the two formates, m- H C O O 2 - and b- H C O O 2 - . This complex region was also analysed at different reaction temperatures. The effect of increasing this operation parameter in the sample is the destabilisation of the superficial species (Fig. S5) due to the lower intensity of the spectrum witnessed. This consequence is more marked for the bidentate carbonate, its peaks located close to 1307 and 1569 cm−1 are more visible at low temperatures and slightly distinguished at 350 °C, suggesting a lower content of this compound at the highest tested temperature. Additionally, the same trend is expected for the monodentate carbonate (however this species had a minor contribution and is practically undetectable at high temperatures). Thus, the thermal stability for these carbonaceous species is assumed as follows: m- C O 3 = ∼ b- C O 3 = < p- C O 3 = , Fig. S5, in agreement with the observation made by Finos et al. [31]. Other species found in this region were the formates, which have shown visible sharp peaks at 1353 cm−1 corresponding to δ(CH) of m − H C O O 2 - , 1370 cm−1 to νs(COO) of b- H C O O 2 - and 1546 cm−1 to νas(COO) of b- H C O O 2 - [35]. Despite these formate bands being located in a complex spectrum, the careful observation of all recorded spectra suggests that their maximum can be found at a moderate temperature in agreement with the corresponding vibrations of ν(CH), ν1(comb), and ν2(comb), already analysed. The evolution of the peak intensity of the main species with the reaction temperature was reported in Fig. 1b, where CO conversion was added, and the minor species were omitted for the sake of clarity. During this analysis, it was assumed that CO conversion was strictly related to WGS activity and then to CO2 (and H2) formation since no undesired or side reactions took place according to MS signals (methanol and methane were absent). At the lowest tested temperature, 100 °C, the CO conversion was practically negligible, but the values increased, smoothly with the reaction temperature up to 250 °C, and then abruptly until 350 °C. Both carbonates showed a small decrease after the temperature was raised to 300 °C, probably by decomposition to CO or CO2, and then exhibited a slight increase between 300 and 350 °C, calling to mind that possibly these species may be unrelated to the evolution of the catalytic activity. On the other hand, the formate production (mono and bidentate) was enhanced from 100 to 250 °C as was noticed for the increased intensity of the signals. Then, a major change occurred from 250 and 350 °C, the evolution was signed by an intensity decrease of both bands indicating a possible reaction not only to WGS products, in line with the higher CO conversion observed, but also due to a possible backward decomposition. In summary, the analysis indicated that WGS products, CO2 and H2, may be obtained from formates since the observed correlation between CO conversion and formates in the 250–350 °C region. Nevertheless, whether an associative mechanism was operative with formate as intermediate, the reaction rates would probably exhibit a maximum at moderate temperatures owing to the limited thermal stability of formates. Therefore, another mechanism should also be taking place like a redox pathway [54] since it is also likely that direct production of CO2 from CePr reduction and H2 generation from H2O oxidation has been conducted during these experiments according to the literature [16]. Thus, an additional analysis should be carried out in order to elucidate this. 3.1.2 Study of the superficial species of the monometallic Cu/CePr catalyst The surface of the copper catalyst was studied at different temperatures in two reaction atmospheres, CO-H2O and CO-H2O-H2. In both cases, the spectra were acquired at steady-state conditions while the gas phase was monitored by mass spectrometry. The evolution of the DRIFTS signals in the presence of CO-H2O is reported in Fig. 2 a. This sample exhibited relevant information for wavenumbers lower than 2400 cm−1, namely 2000–2400 and 1200–1800 cm−1 regions. A small peak corresponding to CO2(g) was observed (2300–2400 cm−1) and wide band of CO between 2000 and 2250 cm−1. This latter changed with the reaction temperature displaying a doublet at the lowest studied temperature, 150 °C, whilst a wide peak appeared at higher values, 350 °C. The observed evolution indicates that a combination of different overlapping signals may took place during the study, being one main contribution the CO(g) with a minor involvement of the often-reported carbonyl adsorbed at Cu+. By analysing the wavenumbers between 1200–1800 cm−1 a series of overlapping bands may be observed. The deconvolution can be found in Fig. S6 and the bands listed in Table 1 in good agreement with the values found for the species of the bare support. The main observed species were mono, bi, and polydentate carbonates, with a minor contribution of bridged carbonate and carboxylate according to the peaks reported elsewhere [18]. It is interesting to note that no appreciable evidence of formate was perceived in the spectra, suggesting that this species is quite likely to be absent during the steady state analysis in the studied temperature range. In consequence, special attention should be paid to other surface species such as a carbonate or carboxylate (− C O 2 δ + ) since were reported as possible reaction intermediates in the literature [55]. By the analysis of the spectra with reaction temperature, it can be observed a clear modification in the intensity of some peaks indicating a change in the surface cover and therefore in the activity of these surface compounds, Fig. S7. When the temperature was increased it was witnessed a shoulder of increasing intensity at 1600–1700 cm−1 where the νas(CO2) vibrations bands of the bridged carbonate and carboxylate are located. However, by observing the evolution of the isolated peak at 1130 cm−1, ascribed to νs(CO2) of br-CO3 =, it was found a marked decrease in intensity which may suggest a surface removal, thus, the main contribution to the shoulder increment may be the carboxylate with a concomitant surface coverage enhancement. Besides, the peak with the maximum located at 1565 cm−1 (ascribed to b-CO3 =) decreased in intensity as well as the one close to 1485 cm−1 (p-CO3 =), although, in a lesser amount. On the other hand, the monodentate carbonate presented a minor contribution to the spectra hindering the possibility of monitoring the evolution with the reaction temperature. The peak intensities are reported in Fig. 2b where CO was added for the sake of clarity. The observed trend indicated that after reaction temperature raise, the CO conversion monotonically increased whilst the main carbonates showed a small decrease in intensity and the carboxylate showed a slight increment. This indicates that the latter surface species behaved as a possible spectator and that there is not feasible evidence to support a strong link between carbonates and CO2 production by WGS, these may have decomposed by the effect of the temperature. As a consequence, a redox mechanism might be considered [54] but additional information is required to enlighten this topic including different reaction conditions and transient analysis (carried out in the next section). The reactivity of the monometallic copper catalyst and the surface species were also studied in the presence of H2 employing a feed gas composition: CO-H2O-H2, 1–3-20 mol ratio and the spectra are reported in Fig. 3 a. The hydrogen addition to the feed stream is relevant due to the operation conditions may change the reaction mechanism and it is not very common to find a reaction study including H2. The spectra of the sample were acquired between 250–350 °C omitting lower temperatures because of the negligible CO conversion at lower values. In all recorded spectra the characteristic signal of hydroxyls was observed at high wavenumbers, CO2(g) at ≈2360 cm−1, CO between 2000–2300 cm−1, and finally the wide region of OCO bands located in 1200–1800 cm−1 range. Additionally, it was identified an incipient signal located at 2830 cm−1 which might indicate the presence of formates. The deconvolution of the wide region at low wavenumbers revealed the coexistence of mono, bi and polydentate carbonates together with monodentate and hydrogen carbonate. The peaks of a possible bidentate species were also added but a minor contribution to the total fitted spectra was found, Fig. S8. Whilst formate and hydrogen carbonate were not present during the previous experiment without hydrogen feed, in H2 presence it was not observed the methoxy species. Then, the stability of some minor species is highly dependent on the reaction conditions. The effect of the reaction temperature on the surface species was analysed by comparing the peak intensities at different temperatures. An enlargement of the section 1200–2000 cm−1 is reported in Fig. S9. The appreciable change in the high wavenumber shoulder of the spectra (1575–1600 cm−1), possibly suggests a forward reaction and/or a backward decomposition of the formate and bicarbonate. On the other hand, the remaining species exhibited minor changes. The peak intensity change with the temperature is reported in Fig. 3b, CO conversion was added to the figure to compare with the evolution of surface species. The results showed that the intensity of the polydentate carbonate practically was not modified, meanwhile, the mono and bidentate carbonates presented a slight decrease after an increment of the temperature. These species presented a very stable behaviour for temperatures lower than 325 °C but a clear change was simultaneously observed for CO conversion. Thus, it may be possible that these three species are not directly related to the CO conversion and therefore with the catalytic activity of the solid acting as merely spectators. Regarding formate and bicarbonate, the contribution to the total spectra was difficult to correlate with the reaction temperature variation due to the inherent error of semiquantitative analysis of minor species, Fig. S8. In addition, both species were absent in the previous reaction conditions suggesting that may not effectively contribute to the reaction extent. Consequently, it was not found strong evidence supporting an associative mechanism for this solid. 3.1.3 Study of the superficial species of the monometallic Ni/CePr catalyst Ni-based solids were reported as suitable alternatives to traditional HTS catalysts due to the promising activity shown at high temperatures and high sintering resistance [8]. Even though these are positive features, the aforesaid samples can also catalyse the hydrogenation of CO and CO2 especially when a high H2 content is present at the reaction feed. Ni ceria solids were also successfully tested as catalysts for CO2 methanation [56,57]. Consequently, the catalytic behaviour of the studied sample, Ni/CePr, is far more complicated than the monometallic copper catalyst previously discussed, thus, more attention should be paid to DRIFTS characterization owing to different reactions that may simultaneously take place even with the same intermediate species. The sample was firstly submitted to a mixture of reactants, CO + H2O (Ar balanced), at different reaction temperatures and the spectra are depicted in Fig. 4 a. Four main regions were identified, hydroxyls at high wavenumbers (>3500 cm−1), C–H vibrations bands of formates between 2800–2900 cm−1, gaseous CO2 (2300–2400 cm−1), and several overlapped peaks ascribed to COO vibrations (1200–1800 cm−1). The signals of adsorbed and gaseous carbon monoxide (1900–2100 cm−1) were almost indistinguishable and no evidence of CH4(g) was found in these particular reaction conditions. By raising the temperature, a change in practically all signals was observed. The surface hydroxyls showed a modest decrease in intensity suggesting a possible consumption to produce other species. The formate (monitored by the C–H bands) presented an appreciable intensity at low temperatures and monotonically decreased until almost a complete disappearance at 300 °C in contrast with the bare support that hosted formates up to 350 °C. The trend observed for the catalyst may imply that a decomposition or conversion to a further intermediate (or both consequences) took place. On the contrary, the CO2(g) presented a sustainable increase clearly indicating a higher WGS activity after a temperature escalation. The most complex analysis arises from the region of the COO vibrations. The mono and polydentate carbonates practically did not show a relevant change with the reaction temperature, whereas the b-CO3 = presented a moderate reduction as it can be concluded by monitoring the shoulder located at 1575 cm−1 (a deconvolution and a proper enlargement of this region can be found in Fig. S10 in Fig. S11 respectively). The overall analysis of the behaviour of the main species with reaction temperature was summarised in Fig. 4b where the CO conversion was added for the sake of comparison. This last feature presented the expected trend, a monotonous increase in temperature in the entire studied range. However, the surface species showed different behaviours. The analysis of carbonates indicates that m - C O 3 = and p - C O 3 = are very stable compounds in this studied sample. On the other hand, a decomposition of the bidentate carbonate was observed with the reaction temperature, but no evidence was found to correlate this compound evolution with a steady CO2 production in contrast with the observation made by Chammankid et al. for their Ni-Ce-Zr catalyst [58]. They stated that carbonate decomposition is a possible source of CO2(g) but this assumption may rely on the overall analysis of the entire region instead of performing a distinction of diverse carbonate evolutions as it was reported in the present work. Another relevant species of the study is the bidentate formate that showed a marked diminution with temperature between 150–300 °C. It is interesting to mention that this behaviour is in line with the trend of lower hydroxyl presence with temperature and higher gaseous CO2 concentration. As a consequence, the formate might be one of the reaction intermediates of the WGS mechanism produced by the adsorbed species, CO and –OH, as was claimed by some authors [58,59]. In fact, Barrio et al. alleged that formate and carbonates may simultaneously be the key determining intermediates in WGS. An additional analysis was carried out in the presence of H2 at the reaction feed in addition to CO + H2O. The collected spectra have shown considerable OH bands at high wavenumbers, small bands of C–H vibrations of formates (2800–2900 cm−1), CO2(g) and CO bands in the 2000–2400 cm−1 range, and the predictable overlapped bands of formates and carbonates located between 1200–1800 cm−1, Fig. 5 a. A marked discrepancy with Fig. 7 , previous experience with CO + H2O, is the exhibition of the high content of methane in all studied temperatures identified by the distinctive band at 3015 cm−1 [60]; the sharp band approximatively at 1305 cm−1 was also observed but this was usually omitted from our analysis due to the complexity of properly quantifying its intensity. The CH4 presence is a typical feature of the nickel catalyst when tested in more real Water Gas Shift conditions and the undesired methanation of CO and CO2 reactions often take place. Another distinction between the spectra in H2 presence is the formate intensity with the reaction temperature, an extended stability was observed up to 350 °C in contrast with practically no appreciable bands further 300 °C in H2 absence at reaction feed. By observing the most complex fraction of the spectra, at 1200–1800 cm−1, it can be found a noticeable intensity decrease in the entire region especially of the high wavenumber shoulder (1500–1600 cm−1) until almost vanishing (Fig. S11). To properly assess these observations, it was attempted a deconvolution of this region of the collected spectrum at 250 °C, Fig. S12. It was found a relevant surface coverage of carbonates (polydentate was the main species), appreciable bands of bidentate formate, and a small peak of CH4(g). Consequently, it can be stated that the H2 addition to the reaction cell feed has not induced any other new species attached to the sample surface. This suggests that methanation reactions and Water Gas Shift if conducted by an associative mechanism might be carried out both by the same reaction intermediates already detected, formate and/or carbonates. However, further conversion of these species to other unstable intermediates should not be rolled out. The evolution of the main bands of formate and carbonates with the reaction temperature was reported in Fig. 5b. This analysis includes the total CO conversion because not only Water Gas Shift but also methanation reactions took place during the experiments. Also, the gas methane signal was monitored and considered. The characteristic band of CH4(g) and the CO conversion curves practically followed the same trend suggesting that selectivity towards WGS is disfavoured in these newly studied conditions, in line with the results found for fixed bed reactor tests in previous works [23]. It is interesting to note that all surface species decreased in coverage after a temperature increase, indicating a comprehensible decomposition. The bidentate carbonate presented a similar trend as the previous analysis without H2 at reaction feed, but the intensity showed a marked decrease in the present case. The other two carbonates also showed a reduction of the corresponding bands insinuating a lower stability in the presence of H2. In addition, the formate displayed a similar evolution with a major surface coverage found at the lower studied temperature and a practically absent band at 375 °C. These trends occurred with the concomitant increase of the total CO conversion and methane production which might suggest a possible relation. Zhou and Liu conducted a DFT analysis on a Ni(111) surface to study different reaction pathways for WGS and CO methanation. The authors reported that the precursor of formate, the formyl group (CHO), is the only major intermediate that participates in both reaction networks [61]. This is in agreement with the findings of Schild et al. for Ni supported over zirconia [62]. Moreover, Yu et al. studied the CO2 methanation on a Ni-ceria surface between 25 and 400 °C. As a result, it was observed a decrease in the main signals of carbonate during the entire experiment and the generation of formates between 200 and 350 °C. They hypothesise that the adsorbed CO2 in the form of carboxylate, carbonate, and bicarbonate, reacted with pre-adsorbed H-producing formates as a main intermediate species for methane generation [57]. However, Villagra-Soza et al. reported the formation of unreactive HCOO* species (spectator), which generate a lower density of methane intermediates in the methanation reaction carried out in NiCo/SiO2 catalysts [63]. Thus, the role of formate is still in controversy. In summary, the results of the studied catalysts showed some similarities but also differences. On the one hand, both active metals promoted the decomposition of bidentate carbonate at high temperatures in contrast with the bare support. On the other hand, the formates showed a quite different behaviour, this species was not found in the monometallic Cu/CePr catalyst in any reaction temperature (150–350 °C) nor conditions (CO-H2O/CO-H2O-H2), suggesting that Cu favoured a quick conversion or even hindered the production. The Ni/CePr surface hosted formates (150–350 °C) as well as the CePr bare support with a suspected difference between species assessed in the 3.1.2 subsection. By taking into account this evidence, it might be assumed that some slow or unreactive formates are linked to the CePr bare support, Fig. 1a, and some other formates species, probably close to Ni particles, might be prone to decompose to products in line with the lower stability found with the reaction temperature, Figs. 4a and 5a. This will be discussed in Section 3.2. 3.1.4 Study of the superficial species of the bimetallic CuNi/CePr catalyst The CuNi bimetallic active phase over ceria support acquired relevance for WGS in the last years, only a few works were published and most of them were related to a catalytic performance study. The bimetallic phase is attractive because a Cu addition to the Ni phase greatly improves the WGS selectivity hindering the undesired Sabatier’s reactions of CO and CO2 to methane typically of Ni-containing catalysts as it was mentioned above. Hence, a more complex spectrum may be expected. The catalytic solid was tested at different reaction temperatures in the presence of CO-H2O and the collected spectra were reported in Fig. 6a. Different species were detected at all studied temperatures: hydroxyls, gaseous carbon dioxide, and carbonates. Formates were not found at any temperature in agreement with the spectra acquired at analogous reaction conditions of monometallic copper catalyst (Fig. 2a) in contrast with those of monometallic nickel (Fig. 4a). An additional signal at 2094 cm−1 was only observed in spectra at temperatures lower than 175 °C. This small peak may be ascribed to adsorbed CO on active metal particles, which is favoured at low temperatures. Kitla et al. reported a comprehensive summary of CO adsorbed signals on different nickel particles, Ni2+–CO carbonyls (2150–2180 cm−1), Ni+–CO monocarbonyls (2160–2100 cm−1), Ni+–CO dicarbonyls (νs(CO) 2131–2145 cm−1 and νas(CO) at 2083–2100 cm−1) and Ni0-CO (2050–2094 cm−1) [64] but it was only a fair coincidence with the monitored signal, suggesting that is probably not related to CO adsorption on isolated Ni particles. On the other hand, Lopez-Cámara and co-workers studied the reaction mechanism of a Cu-ceria sample by DRIFTS-MS, the acquired spectra showed a band at 2095 cm−1 after a CO step and was attributed to carbonyl species adsorbed on Cu particles [45]. It is worth mentioning that this signal was not found in previous monometallic samples, which might be due to the presence of smaller particles prone to absorb CO molecules [65]. The complex region located between 1100–1600 cm−1 was deconvoluted and three different carbonates were found (Fig. S13). Practically mono, bi, and polydentate carbonates equally contributed to the spectrum suggesting a balanced presence of these compounds. Other authors reported the presence of carboxylate for their CuNi/CeO2 samples at very similar positions to mono and bidentate carbonates [39]. The inclusion of these highly overlapped peaks would imply an inaccurate deconvolution and only carbonates were considered during fitting. The reaction temperature effect on surface species was studied between 125 and 300 °C. The hydroxyls showed a noticeable decrease indicating a possible enhanced conversion by the temperature rise. In line with this trend, a simultaneous increase in the CO2 signal suggests a higher conversion of CO with temperature as it is expected. On the other hand, the entire carbonate region showed a minor change (Fig. S14), which implies that the three compounds are strongly attached to the sample surface. The differentiated contributions of carbonates are plotted in Fig. 6b. It can be observed that mono and bidentate carbonates presented a moderate decrease with the reaction temperature whilst the polydentate practically did not exhibit any change. The carbon monoxide conversion was also reported in the same figure in order to correlate the surface species presence and the catalytic activity of the sample. Since no other species except carbonates were virtually found during the tests, the observed catalytic activity of the sample should probably be explained by a redox mechanism instead of an associative one. This is a difference with some works of the literature. Saw et al. reported a collection of DRIFTS spectra for CuNi/CeO2 between 25 and 600 °C in which observed carbonates, and carboxylates after a CO step, and formates only 200–400 °C [66]. Consequently, the authors proposed three different kinetics ascribed to a redox, an associative via formate, and an associative via carboxylate mechanisms being the best fit to fixed bed CO conversion results the last mechanism, disregarding the formate mediated path [13]. However, a possible combination between redox and associative via carboxylate was not ruled out due to both similar goodness of fit. In the present work, an extra analysis was carried out in order to elucidate the Cu and Ni interaction with surface species. The bimetallic sample was studied at different temperatures in a steady state flow with CO-H2O-H2 as a more realistic WGS feed, Fig. 7a after a H2 step as same as the conducted study for Ni/CePr catalyst. The spectra were collected between 250 and 375 °C. Once more, the hydroxyls region presented an acceptable intensity as well as CO2(g) and the complex region between 1200–1800 cm−1 in line with the previous spectra acquired in the presence of CO-H2O. On the contrary, an evident gaseous methane signal was found for reaction temperatures higher than 300 °C. Another relevant signal witnessed in the bimetallic surface was formate, previously absent in CO-H2O feed indicating that H2 presence enhanced the formation of this specie. This same behaviour was also noticed for the Ni/CePr catalytic solid. The region with wavenumbers between 1200–1800 cm−1 was deconvoluted including three carbonate species (mono, bi, and polydentate), CH4(g), and bidentate formate, Fig. S15. The polydentate carbonate was the main contribution to the region, followed by mono and bidentate with relevant intensities, and CH4 and formate with a minimal impact on the fitting result. The reaction temperature evidently affected most of the species present in the sample surface, Fig. S16. The peak intensities of all relevant species were plotted against the reaction temperature in Fig. 7b. The methane increased from almost an unimportant side production to practically a main product between 275 and 375 °C. Simultaneous with methane production, the CO2(g) observed in DRIFTS spectra increased until a maximum production close to 300–325 °C and then decreased at higher temperatures implying competitive paths between CH4 and CO2 formation. The observation is in fair agreement with the monometallic Ni sample characterised in the same conditions, however, this latter was prone to CH4 production at a lower temperature (presumably less than 250 °C, Fig. 6a). Thus, it can be concluded that this is a specific feature of Cu modulating behaviour of Ni particles prone to produce methanation. Salcedo and Irigoyen studied a CuNi sample supported over Ceria surface with structural defects in order to determine the Cu role in CO activity [16]. The authors concluded that CO desorption is more likely than CO dissociation on bimetallic Ni–Cu and pure Cu clusters. Thus, from a thermodynamic point of view, the undesired CO methanation reaction becomes unfavorable upon addition of Cu explaining the highest selectivity towards WGS i.e.: low methane yield. Based on a previous analysis, it can be claimed this feature is not related to the metallic content since a solid with 5 % of Ni showed a stronger tendency to methane production [14], suggesting that an electronic or size effect may be responsible. Different arguments were found in the literature to explain this feature. Arbelaez et al. argued that the bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts were improved in comparison with Ni one, due to the existence of a Cu0-NiOx interface with an electronic exchange between both faces favouring the reactant molecules activation [67]. Other authors explained the great selectivity by the presence of the Cu-Ni alloy by XRD and EXAFS [68]. Moreover, the enhanced reducibility of the sample suggested a possible interaction between Cu (easily reducible) and Ni (less reducible) [64,69]. This enhanced reducibility might be responsible for the higher stability of adsorbed CO on Ni particles hindering the C-O cleavage that leads to CH4 formation. In addition to the methane signal analysis, the other solid species also showed a distinctive behaviour in the bimetallic solid. The bidentate formate evidenced a monotonic decrease in intensity during the test suggesting an enhanced decomposition with increasing temperature. The bidentate carbonates showed a decline, and the mono and polydentate carbonates exhibited a minor drop with the reaction temperature. This trend was very similar to the previously observed for the same sample in H2 absence (CO and H2O as reaction feed), indicating a high stability of carbonates even in the presence of high H2 content. The analysis of the entire spectra suggested to two main conclusions. Firstly, the CO2 production in the bimetallic solid might not be related to any surface species. Secondly, when H2 is also fed to the reactor cell, the presence causes methane formation as it may be expected because of the Ni presence, but this is highly modulated by a bimetallic Cu-Ni interaction with a possible effect on formate species. 3.2 Transient analysis of samples The steady-state analysis previously performed helped to identify the present species, the effect of the active metal on their stability, and to perform a first approximation to a possible reaction mechanism. This analysis should be complemented with a transient response method of the studied samples to effectively correlate the behaviour of the surface species with the content of the reactants and products. Thus, a sharp and abrupt change of the reaction atmosphere was introduced into the cell after achieving a steady state. The steam stream was constant during all step analysis, and CO or H2 was introduced due to the quicker fluid dynamic response of CO and H2 in the cell. The main and more relevant surface species were continuously monitored together with CH4(g) and CO2(g) by DRIFTS; minor species were omitted from the analysis due to the large associated error inherent to small peaks quantification. In all cases, the sample surface before the step was used as background. After a CO step with a constant water fraction, a series of reactions may produce different products and possible intermediates. In agreement with the simplified nomenclature introduced by Kalaramas et al. [48], the reactions that led to formate, CO2, and carbonate might be: Formate formation: (1) CO ( g ) + s → k 1 C O - s (2) H 2 O + s → k 2 H 2 O - s (3) H 2 O - s + s ′ → k 3 H O - s ′ + H - s (4) CO - s + O H - s ′ → k 4 H C O O - s - s ′ (5) HCOO - s - s ′ → k 5 C O 2 g + H - s + s ′ Bidentate carbonate formation: (6) CO - s + O - s ′ → k 6 C O 2 - s ′ - s (7) C O 2 - s ′ - s + O - s ′ → k 7 b - C O 3 - s 2 ′ + s Redox path: (8) CO - s + O - s ′ → k 8 C O 2 ( g ) + s ′ + s (9) HO - s ′ + H - s → k 9 H 2 g + O - s ′ + s The aforementioned equations are referring to the transient evolution after an instantaneous and sharp step of CO, with a constant surplus of H2O in the reaction feed (CO:H2O, 1:3 M ratio) over an assumed clean surface, i.e., reverse reactions may be disregarded. In addition, s and s’ are different active sites representing the active metal (Cu, CuNi, or Ni), and the oxidised cation of the support (Ce4+ or Pr4+), respectively; the equations involving the polydentate carbonates are reported in the Supplementary material. The equation set utilised to model the temporal evolutions is the following: Formates equations: (10) d C CO dt = Fv V C CO in - Fv V C CO - k 1 C CO (11) d C CO - s dt = k 1 C CO - k 4 C OH - s ′ C CO - s (12) d C HCOO - s - s ′ dt = k 4 C OH - s ′ C CO - s - k 5 C HCOO - s - s ′ (13) d C C O 2 dt = - Fv V C C O 2 + k 5 C HCOO - s - s ′ + k 8 C O - s ″ C CO - s Bidentate carbonate equations: (14) d C C O 2 - s ′ - s dt = k 6 C O - s ′ C CO - s - k 7 C O - s ′ C CO - s ′ - s (15) d C b - C O 3 - s 2 ′ dt = k 7 C O - s ′ C CO - s ′ - s The equations were integrated, and the solution is a combination of decreasing exponential functions as expected, i.e., negative arguments; a generic expected solution is reported in the Supplementary material for the sake of clarity. A particular result is usually taken into account in the analysis, when one reaction is much slower than the others. In that specific case all other exponentials may achieve a very low value quite quick leading to a single reaction in the set, known as pseudo-stationary model. As a result, only one exponential function is required to explain the temporal evolution since all other values already achieved the steady state since no reaction set is involved. The bare support was analysed after a CO step was introduced with a constant H2O/Ar atmosphere, H2O/Ar → CO + H2O/Ar. Bidentate formate and carbonates (bidentate and polydentate) were easily identified. However, it was not possible to scrutinise every spectrum to find the evolution of monodentate formate and monodentate carbonate, suggesting a negligible contribution of both to each spectrum. The peak areas for each relevant species were plotted versus the reaction time in Fig. S15. By analysing the temporal evolution of each species, it can be inferred not only the trivial conclusion, that CO and carbonates are strictly related, but also that carbonates presented an evolution proper of a stable molecule without a further decomposition step, i.e., a spectator. The bidentate carbonate has shown a faster evolution than the polydentate, reaching its plateau before. On the other hand, the bidentate formate exhibited a slower and slagged temporal evolution characteristic of a species simultaneously involved in different reactions, possibly generation and consumption. In order to corroborate all these assumptions, the curves were fitted with exponential functions, being the natural response times (the inverse of the reaction rate constants [48]) the most relevant parameter. The values found for bidentate and polydentate carbonates were 1.8 and 2.3 min, respectively (Table S2), reinforcing the faster evolution of the bidentate species. Consequently, the formate curve was fitted with a combination of two exponentials to properly account for this behaviour. The obtained natural time responses were quite diverse from each other, which may indicate a quick formation and a slow decomposition. Since formates are often proposed as reaction intermediates, and the steady state analysis special attention must be paid to a possible link between these attached species and CO2The evolution of the gaseous product was monitored by the IR signal at 2340 cm−1, showing an atypical curve with two simultaneous phenomena taking place, one achieving a steady state continuously producing CO2 from CO, and the remaining exhibiting a maximum contribution to the overall CO2 production. In agreement with this observation, the m/z spectral signals evidenced H2 and CO2 detached temporal curves with a maximum in the CO2 production and a delay in hydrogen evolution. This necessarily implies the reduction of the superficial ceria-praseodymia by CO, viz., Oxygen Storage Capacity (OSC) [24] and marked redox activity. By taking this phenomenon into account, only the stable contribution to CO2 of the IR signal was fitted to compare with the other. The obtained natural time (a rough approximation) indicated that the gaseous product evolves faster than the bidentate formate and therefore, there is no possible relation between species [70]. As a result, transient IR signals and mass spectra may imply that the redox mechanism is taking place, whilst the associative mechanism by formates, if present, may have a minor role. This is in agreement with the findings of Salcedo and Irigoyen [16]. The study was conducted by DFT on a ceria sample with surface oxygen defects (partially reduced). The obtained results indicated that at a low temperature, a redox-associative mechanism may take place. In this case, the intermediate species, formate, decomposed to CO2 whilst an adsorbed CO on Ce4+ sites allow for CO2 release, forming an oxygen vacancy in a faster step. This path is shown in the scheme depicted in Fig. 9a, where V represents an oxygen vacancy due to the support reaction (Ce4+/Ce3+, or Pr4+/Pr3+) in the redox path. This involves the reduction of the support by CO (as previously mentioned) and the oxidation by OH, with the concomitant replenishment of the O, leading to a H attached to the surface. This species then reacts with others to form H2(g), closing the cycle. Moreover, in Fig. 9a it was also included the possible steps leading to carbonate formation, a spectator according to the experimental results, as well as the formate observed in both transient and steady state experiments. The transient analysis was also performed for the Cu/CePr sample. Again, a CO step over a constant flow of H2O/Ar was conducted. Carboxy and bridge carbonates, both absent in all the collected spectra in the entire OCO region (1200–1800 cm−1) have led to a few relevant signals to monitor. Bidentate and polydentate carbonates were observed in all spectra together with CO2(g). The evolution of the integrated peak areas with time is reported in Fig. 8 b to compare with the bare support behaviour in the same reaction conditions. The bidentate and polydentate carbonates exhibited almost identical and peculiar evolutions since a maximum was observed because of the CO step. This suggests that the surface species were generated and then consumed or decomposed until reaching a minor content at the end of the analysis, even lower than the original surface, indicating a possible previous saturation of the surface. The temporal evolutions were successfully fitted with a combination of two exponential functions, signifying that a formation-decomposition model may be accurate. Surprisingly, the obtained natural times for both carbonates in Cu/CePr were similar to those fitted to the bare CePr support, which suggests the formation is possibly independent of the Cu presence and thus might be strictly related to ceria-praseodymia surface, which is known to be prone to form carbonates [30]. It is interesting to mention that the corresponding signal of the gaseous CO2 presented an increase until reaching a plateau after the CO step, revealing that no relation may be found between the carbonates and the CO2 (g), Fig. 8b. According to previous evidence, this monometallic copper catalyst likely operates through a redox mechanism due to the redox synergy that is exhibited by the Cu-ceria catalysts. This is particularly relevant when a redox promoter such as Pr is present [24], since this element greatly improves the redox capacity of the oxide and oxygen mobility. Hence, this reaction path is consistent with the findings of Koriabkyna et al [71] suggesting a redox path. The estimated scheme is exhibited in Fig. 9b. This shows the main steps involving the CO adsorption in the metal active site, and the water splitting in the Cu-CePr interface owing to its inherent redox activity [54]. Thus, the CO reduces the tetravalent cations of the support, whilst the OH oxidise them. Finally, the H attached to the support surface and active metal are combined to release H2. In addition, the carbonate formation was also introduced for the sake of completeness. It is expected that this involves a series of steps, firstly with the carbon of CO attached to the active metal, and then to the oxygen atoms of the support. The monometallic Ni catalyst was also submitted to a transient response analysis, as in the previous samples, but the current study involved different approaches because of the relevant trend exhibited by this solid to methane formation through undesired side reactions. The first analysis involved a CO step (H2O/Ar → CO + H2O/Ar), and the temporal evolution of all species (integrated peak areas versus time) is reported in Fig. 10 a. As a result of the CO step, CH4 was found, but the temporal evolution was completely transitory. This achieved practically a null value at the end of the analysis. A small content of CH4 was quickly formed, probably by consuming −H species previously attached to the sample surface due to the fixed steam stream, and then removed from the cell. This steady state agrees with the spectra acquired in Fig. 7, with methane absent in the spectra. A similar evolution was observed for CO2(g), also presenting a maximum during the CO step, and then followed by a plateau. This behaviour may be due to a combination of a fast and transient generation and a slower CO2 production, as it was also observed for the copper catalyst. According to the simultaneous analysis of mass spectra, the m/z signals of CO2 and H2 were slightly delayed at the beginning of the experiment, but both synchronised a few moments later. As a result, the maximum might be due to an oxygen removal of the sample ascribed to a quick OSC response of the support enhanced by the Ni presence [69], whilst the steady state evolution might be related to WGS activity. In addition to the gaseous CH4 and CO2 species, the bidentate and polydentate carbonates were also identified. No signals of the monodentate carbonate or formate bands were observed, but an incipient formate signal might have appeared in the spectra at the beginning of the analysis, quickly vanishing later. The temporal evolution of both carbonates indicated that the two species achieved a stable content on the surface of the catalyst, owing to a spectator behaviour with no resemblance to CO2 or CH4 evolutions. Since the monometallic Ni catalyst is capable of producing methane by a different but related path to the Water Gas Shift reaction, the hydrogen effect on activity and selectivity was also studied, Fig. 10b. This second analysis conducted on the Ni catalyst involved a H2 step to a constant stream of CO + H2O/Ar. As a result, several signals were identified and monitored, bidentate and polydentate carbonates as same as before, CO2 as it was expected, but also, bidentate formate and a stable CH4(g) evolution. All identified species were integrated by considering the most relevant peaks, and the temporal evolutions were reported in Fig. 11 b. An obvious change was noticed in the gaseous species, the methane fraction increased whilst the carbon dioxide diminished until it reached a constant value. Both curves were crossed far from the medium point of 0.5 of normalised intensity (actually the point was close to 0.65) and thus it may be assumed that these species are not obtained from the same intermediate [72] and that the observed trend was due to the competence of both reactions, Methanation and Water Gas Shift, for the common reactant, carbon monoxide. Regarding the surface species, both carbonates presented practically invariable values, indicating that these species are not disturbed in the present reaction conditions. These are kept attached to the surface, signifying that no relation may be expected between carbonates and formate, nor between carbonates of any reaction product, CH4 or CO2. On the other hand, the presence of formate is related to the introduced H2. It is interesting to note that formate was also present on the surface of the bare support and is only found in the Ni catalysts in the case of a high H2 content. This suggests that Cu might destabilise the bidentate formate, whilst Ni might not severely affect this species. In this case, the b-HCOO displayed a monotonous increase with a concavity change and a time lag at the beginning. The complexity of the curve and the combination of these features suggest that this formate species was involved in different reactions, but the time response was slower than CH4 achieving the steady state later, revealing that formate may not be a relevant intermediate species for the production path of this product in this Ni catalyst [61]. The fitting of the temporal evolutions corroborated this observation by the smaller natural time found for CH4 than formates, Table S2. In addition, the CO2 was observed in the absence of formates (previous analysis), whilst in H2 presence, both species exhibited contrary evolutions. All evidence indicates that formate may not be related to CO2. In summary, the carbonates were found as possible spectators unconnected to the gaseous products, irrespective of the reaction conditions. Meanwhile, the bidentate formate was observed when H2 was fed to the catalysts, but the temporal evolution, slower than the corresponding methane, indicated that they are not related. Fig. 9c summarises the reaction paths of the WGS and the Methanation reaction according to the experimental findings, also in agreement with the literature. Water and CO are firstly adsorbed in the active metal and then bonded to the high reactivity support interface, with the concomitant water splitting into H and OH in agreement with the reported path of Lustemberg et al. due the cooperative effect of the Ni and ceria [73]; previous H2 splitting step in the sample surface was omitted in the figure for the sake of simplicity. The next step in the mechanism may be the formation of COH species as it was reported by Zhou et al. in a Ni(111) clean surface. The authors compared by DFT the most competitive pathways for WGS and the Methanation reaction and reported that both reactions may share this same intermediate. This species is suitable to be further converted into HCOO and CO2 through the WGS pathway (right path in Fig. 9c), or further decompose into CH and then to produce CH4 (left path in Fig. 9c). Nevertheless, Carrasco et al. studied a Ni/Ceria surface and reported an oxidative CO adsorption, which produces weakly bound CO2 species on the bare CeO2(111) support but stronger bound species on the Ni/CeO2(111) systems [74]. Therefore, the analysis of the Ni catalyst suggests that a redox mechanism and a weak associative (mediated by other species not recognised in the present work) may be occurring. The bimetallic catalyst was tested by a transient state response analysis, the same as the other samples. During the CO step, the signals of two carbonates were observed, and the temporal evolution of these surface species was reported together with the gaseous carbon dioxide evolution, Fig. 11a. No formate signals were found in agreement with the monometallic catalysts, nor any methane peak. The two carbonates presented a simple temporal evolution achieving a steady state, but the polydentate carbonate exhibited a faster evolution than bidentate in clear contrast with the tendency observed in the bare support and the monometallic catalysts. On the other hand, the CO2 evolution exhibited a fast increase followed by a slow response. This profile necessarily implies some reaction steps ending in CO2 production and then elution of the cell, instead of a direct formation as same as carbonates, with carbonates as spectators and a minor role of the formates, Fig. 11a. Since this solid presented some tendency to produce the aforementioned side product, methane, not only a CO step was conducted, but also a H2 step as a complementary procedure. In this case, not only were both carbonate types detected, but also the bidentate formate, in agreement with the monometallic Ni catalyst behaviour. In addition, the CO2(g) evolution was measured, and the gaseous methane signals were also found in agreement with the steady state analysis. The monitored five temporal evolutions were reported in Fig. 10b with a collected background on the sample previous to the H2 step. The carbonates showed a quick and minor evolution, revealing that H2 induced a very little or null effect on these surface species in contrast with the Ni monometallic catalyst. On the other hand, the intensity of the formate species increased after the H2 step, suggesting that this species may be formed by the presence of CO and the available H attached at the solid surface, in this case, from the introduced H2. The temporal evolution of formates was slightly more complex, involving different reaction steps, likely formation and decomposition. The methane displayed a constant increase with time, and the CO2 showed a clear decrease. However, the crossover of the gaseous products occurred at ≈0.45 of normalised intensity, which may imply a slower evolution of methane production in contrast with the monometallic Ni catalyst behaviour in the same reaction conditions, Fig. 11b. The methane time evolution achieved a steady state slightly after the formate, which might imply a possible relation between the species. Alternatively, the CO2 evolution is not related to the formation of the stable carbonates (irrespective of the reaction conditions tested), either with the formate, since this was not identified in the H2 absence and was observed in CO2 production. Then, a redox mechanism should be taking place in this catalyst. Therefore, this path is reported in Fig. 9d, including the adsorption of the CO and the water in the CuNi active metal site. This is preferably conducted in sites close to an oxygen vacancy due to these are highly effective in completing the water dissociation into OH and H. It was reported that the dissociation may be the slowest step rather than the CO adsorption and its further conversion into CO2 [75], in agreement with the high OSC found for this solid in previous works of the research group [23]. In addition, the carbonate formation was also included in the figure, following the same path as in the monometallic Cu catalyst. 4 Conclusions The results obtained in this study highlight the complex interplay between active metals and the CePr support in determining the nature of surface intermediates and the prevailing mechanism in the Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction. While it is well established that an active metal introduction modifies the catalytic behaviour of ceria-based supports, the present findings provide new insights into the ongoing discussion of redox versus associative pathways, particularly regarding the role of formate species. The bare CePr support exhibited a variety of surface species across the investigated temperature range under CO and H2O feed. Steady-state and transient analyses indicated that carbonates acted as spectator species and that formates, although present, likely contribute only marginally to CO2 formation. These results and the well-known redox properties of non-stoichiometric ceria-praseodymia systems suggest that a redox mechanism predominates in the absence of metallic promoters. The incorporation of Cu significantly altered surface speciation. Notably, formates were not observed under any tested condition, while carbonates, detected in all cases, did not correlate with CO2 production and were again assumed to be spectators. These observations, in line with the enhanced redox character of Cu/CePr reported in previous studies, supported the operation of a redox pathway facilitated by synergistic interactions between Cu and the reducible support. Supported Ni as an active metal was not capable of destabilising the formate, in contrast with the Cu active metal. Formate might not be correlated with CO2 formation because the transient evolutions showed CO2 without an appreciable formate presence. Although a minor contribution to the overall CO2 generation might not be disregarded, formate might not be correlated with CO2 since the evidence of the steady state analysis is not conclusive, and the transient evolutions showed CO2 without an appreciable formate presence. Additionally, formate species were observed in the absence of appreciable methane production, and the results of the transient analysis proved that methane evolution was faster than formate formation, signifying that no possible correlation is possible between formate and the side product. The three different identified carbonates were merely spectators as it was concluded by the steady state thermal and transient temporal evolutions (steady state and transient state, respectively). Therefore, the WGS might be proceeding via a redox mechanism on Ni/CePr catalyst simultaneously with the methanation reactions. The CePr-supported bimetallic CuNi solid exhibited a particular catalytic behaviour. In the absence of H2, only stable carbonates with the reaction temperature were observed, in agreement with the performance of both monometallic solids. This suggests that a non-associative mechanism may be occurring. In H2 presence, formates and methane appeared in agreement with the monometallic Ni catalyst behaviour, with a concomitant decrease of CO2 production, probably by the competition of both reactions for the common reactant. Since CO2 was produced before the H2 introduction, formate may not be related or might only slightly contribute to a slight extent to its overall production. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance for Water Gas Shift Reaction and surface species at reaction conditions were studied by operando-DRIFTS of the bare Pr-promoted Ce oxide support, two supported monometallic Cu and Ni, and a bimetallic CuNi catalyst. All samples were thoroughly characterised by Operando-DRIFTS across a range of temperatures (150–375 °C) and two distinct reaction atmospheres: CO–H2O and CO–H2O–H2. The results demonstrated that the nature of the surrounding atmosphere significantly influences the surface chemistry and product distribution. The reactivity was as follows: CePr < Cu/CePr < CuNi/CePr < Ni/CePr. However, the selectivity towards CO2 was CePr=Cu/CePr > CuNi/CePr > Ni/CePr due to the tendency to produce CH4 (on Ni-containing catalysts) when H2 was present in the reaction feed. Hence, under oxidising conditions (absence of hydrogen), formate species were stabilised on CePr and Ni/CePr surfaces, indicating a predominant associative mechanism. In contrast, Cu-containing catalysts (Cu/CePr and CuNi/CePr) favoured carbonate formation and suppressed formate accumulation, promoting a redox-type pathway. Under reducing conditions (presence of H2), Ni facilitated CH4 formation via methanation, particularly on Ni/CePr. The bimetallic CuNi/CePr catalyst behaved similarly to Cu/CePr under CO–H2O feed, showing no stable formates, but in the presence of H2, methane formation and surface-stabilised formates were observed—mimicking the behaviour of Ni/CePr. These findings highlight the role of Cu in modulating the electronic and adsorptive properties of Ni, weakening formate adsorption and delaying methanation, thus enhancing CO2 selectivity. Overall, the CuNi/CePr system emerges as a complex multimetallic catalyst that adapts to both oxidising and reducing environments, improving WGS performance through a balanced interplay between redox and hydrogenation pathways.
